conclusion: The graph shows displacement x as a function of time t.
The slope of the tangent to the curve at any point gives the instantaneous velocity at that time.
Speed is the magnitude of velocity.

premise: The slope of the tangent to the curve at any point is the derivative of x with respect to t.
conclusion: The slope represents the velocity v(t).

premise: We need to find the points where the magnitude of the velocity is 5 m/s.
conclusion: Look for points on the graph where the slope of the tangent line is ±5.
At t = 0, the slope is negative and steep.
As t increases, the slope decreases in magnitude.
At t = 2, the slope is zero (the curve is horizontal).
After t = 2, the slope becomes positive and increases.

premise: Look for points where the tangent line has a slope of 5 or -5.
conclusion: Identify the points where the tangent line appears to have these slopes.

premise: Identify the points where the tangent line appears to have slopes of ±5.
conclusion: There are two points where the slope of the tangent is ±5.
